metadata.case_name: Bombay Port Trust Employees Union v. Trustees of the Port of Bombay

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against award dated September 20, 1963 by Central Government Industrial Tribunal, Bombay in Reference CGIT-25 of 1962 under s.10(2) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.
Appellants are workmen of Bombay Port Trust represented by Bombay Port Trust Employees Union; respondents are Trustees of Port of Bombay.

Reference made on joint application of parties; dispute: Whether existing system of work of shore crew of Princes and Victoria Docks (8 hours normal duty, 2 hours variable recess, 12 hours overtime? - clarified as 8 duty, 2 recess, 2 OT) needs modification.
Tribunal held Union unable to establish need for modification; accepted Trustees' case.
Two-shift system introduced at Alexandra Docks on June 30, 1953; extended to Princes and Victoria Docks on December 15, 1953. Previously single shift liable to call at any hour.
Each 12-hour shift: 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable recess, 2 hours overtime; recess variable due to tides.
In 1956, Port Trust General Workers Union demanded fixed 2-hour recess; Trustees rejected fearing demand for 4 hours OT, threatened three-shift; Union accepted variable recess near middle.
Alexandra Docks: lock gates allow fixed rest (half crew different times); Princes/Victoria: tidal, only high tide work, variable recess informed day before.
Notice under s.9A Industrial Disputes Act on June 25, 1960 for variable recess at Alexandra Docks (fixed otherwise except monsoon).
Studies showed heavier work at Alexandra; changed to 8 hours duty, 1 hour variable recess, 3 hours OT. Not extended to Princes/Victoria/Butcher Island (8 duty, 2 recess, 2 OT) as work not justifying.
Flotilla Crew: 12 hours full duty, 8 work + 4 OT.
Union contends 12-hour shift break-up violates Minimum Wages Act; variable rest illusory (sometimes at start/end); claims 8 work + 4 OT like Flotilla.
Trustees contend no breach of Minimum Wages Act; shore crew at Princes/Victoria/Butcher not comparable to Alexandra or Flotilla due to work hours.

legal_issues.text: Whether the existing system of work (12-hour shift: 8 hours duty, 2 hours variable recess, 2 hours overtime) for shore crew at Princes and Victoria Docks violates ss.13,14 of Minimum Wages Act, 1947 and Rules 24,25 of Minimum Wages Central Rules, 1950.
Whether variable recess satisfies requirements of rest intervals under the Act and Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: Break-up of 12-hour shift into 8 hours duty, 2 hours rest, 2 hours overtime offends Minimum Wages Act; variable recess illusory (given at commencement/end depending on tides/exigencies); should be 8 work + 4 OT like Flotilla Crew.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Minimum Wages Act ss.13,14; Minimum Wages Central Rules 24,25

petitioner_arguments.text: System does not satisfy requirements of rest punctuating hours of work; division unequal compared to Alexandra (3 OT) and Flotilla (4 OT).

respondent_arguments.text: No breach of Minimum Wages Act; actual work hours at Princes/Victoria/Butcher Island do not justify increasing OT to 3 or 4 hours; not comparable to Alexandra or Flotilla due to workload differences.
Variable recess specified in advance; nature of tidal work requires it.

court_reasoning.text: Normal working day under s.13 includes hours of actual duty + specified intervals of rest; Rule 24(1)(a): 9 hours work for adult; Rule 24(2): inclusive of rest, not spread over >12 hours.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between hours of work (max 9/day, 48/week) and specified rest intervals; OT only for work >9 hours/day.

court_reasoning.text: Interval of rest: break where workman on duty but not called for physical activity/sustained attention, specified beforehand.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Variable recess ok if specified in advance; tidal nature justifies variability.

court_reasoning.text: In 12-hour shift, up to 9 hours work + rest intervals without OT; weekly 48 hours max at ordinary rate (8/day avg); OT at double rate beyond.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Port Trust's system (8 work +2 rest +2 OT) compliant as total work 48/week.

court_reasoning.text: No compulsion to break up work hours with rest like Factories Act s.55; different crews not comparable due to work nature.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Time and tide wait for no man; Princes/Victoria tidal docks differ from lock-gate Alexandra or Flotilla.

holdings.text: Existing system does not violate Minimum Wages Act ss.13,14 or Rules 24,25; variable recess permissible if specified in advance; no need for modification.
Different crews not entitled to equal treatment due to differing workloads and dock types.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Reference made under s.10(2); notice under s.9A for change

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixing normal working day inclusive of rest intervals; overtime for excess work

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Central Rules, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: 9 hours normal work day for adult, spread over <=12 hours incl rest; OT at double rate >9 hours/day or 48/week

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Compared for daily hours, rest intervals, spread over; distinguishes as not directly applicable but analogous

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; Tribunal's award upheld as correct; no modification to existing work system required; Trustees not guilty of infraction of Minimum Wages Act.

key_quotes.text: "Time and tide wait for no man. Workers at a tidal dock must work when the tide is in and take their rest when the tide is out."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies variable recess due to tidal nature of work

key_quotes.text: "The normal working day thus includes (a) hours of actual duty, and (b) one or more specified intervals."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines composition of normal working day under s.13

key_quotes.text: "Overtime under s.14 is only payable when the workman works in excess of the number of hours constituting a normal working day. That number is 9 hours for any day."
key_quotes.speaker: court
